column1: Yogyakarta (; also Jogjakarta or Jogja; Javanese: ꦔꦪꦺꦴꦒꦾꦏꦂꦠ

column3: on the island of Java. As the only Indonesian royal city still ruled by a monarchy

column5: batik textiles
column6: drama
column12: and wayang puppetry. Renowned as a centre of Indonesian education
column13: Yogyakarta is home to a large student population and dozens of schools and universities
column15: the country's largest institute of higher education and one of its most prestigious.Yogyakarta is the capital of the Yogyakarta Sultanate and served as the Indonesian capital from 1946 to 1948 during the Indonesian National Revolution
column16: with Gedung Agung as the president's office. One of the districts in southeastern Yogyakarta
column18: was the capital of the Mataram Sultanate between 1587 and 1613.

column1: Yogyakarta is named after the Indian city of Ayodhya
column2: the birthplace of the eponymous hero Rama from the Ramayana epic. Yogya means "suitable; fit; proper"
column3: and karta means "prosperous; flourishing". Thus
column4: Yogyakarta means "[a city that is] fit to prosper".In colonial era correspondence
column5: the city is often written in the Javanese script as ꦔꦪꦺꦴꦒꦾꦏꦂꦠ
column6: read as  with the added prefix nga-. In the orthography of the time
column7: the proper name was spelt with the Latin alphabet as "Jogjakarta". As the orthography of the Indonesian language changed
column8: the consonant  came to be written with <y>
column9: and the consonant  with <j>. Personal and geographical names however
column10: were allowed to maintain their original spelling according to contemporary Indonesian orthography. Thus
column11: the city can be written as "Yogyakarta"
column12: which is true to its original pronunciation and the Javanese script spelling
column14: which is true to the old Dutch spelling and reflects popular pronunciation today
column15: but differs from the original Ayodhya etymology. One may encounter either "Yogyakarta" or "Jogjakarta" in contemporary documents.

column1: According to the Canggal inscription dated 732 CE
column2: the area traditionally known as "Mataram" became the capital of the Medang Kingdom
column3: identified as Mdang i Bhumi Mataram established by King Sanjaya of Mataram. The inscription was found in a Hindu temple in Central Java
column4: 40 km away from Yogyakarta and 20 km away from the giant Borobudur temple complex. This Hindu temple itself was on the border between the area of the Hindu Sañjaya dynasty and the area of the Buddhist Shailendra dynasty. Mataram became the centre of a refined and sophisticated Javanese Hindu-Buddhist culture for about three centuries in the heartland of the Progo River valley
column5: on the southern slopes of Mount Merapi volcano. This time period witnessed the construction of numerous candi
column6: including Borobudur and Prambanan.

column2: the last ruler of the Sañjaya dynasty
column3: King Mpu Sindok of Mataram
column4: moved the seat of power of the Mataram Kingdom from Central Java to East Java and thus established the Isyana dynasty. The exact cause of the move is still uncertain; however
column5: a severe eruption from Mount Merapi or a power struggle with the Sumatra-based Srivijaya kingdom probably caused the move. Historians suggest that some time during the reign of King Wawa of Mataram (924–929 CE)
column6: Merapi erupted and devastated the kingdom's capital in Mataram.

column2: the area surrounding modern Yogyakarta was identified again as "Mataram" and recognised as one of the twelve Majapahit provinces in Java ruled by a Duke known as Bhre Mataram. During the reign of the fourth king of the Majapahit Empire
column3: the Hindu King Hayam Wuruk (1350–1389) of the Rajasa dynasty
column4: the title of Bhre Mataram was held by the king's nephew and son-in-law Wikramawardhana
column5: later the fifth king of Majapahit.

column2: now a district in southeastern Yogyakarta
column3: was established as the capital of the Mataram Sultanate from 1587–1613. During the reign of Sultan Agung Hanyokrokusumo (1613–1645)
column4: the Mataram Sultanate reached its zenith as the greatest kingdom in Java
column5: and expanded its influence to Central Java
column6: East Java
column7: and half of West Java. After two changes of capital—to Karta and then to Plered
column8: both located in present-day Bantul Regency—the capital of the Mataram Sultanate finally moved to Kartasura.

column1: A civil war in the Mataram Sultanate broke out between Pakubuwono II (1745–1749)
column2: the last ruler of Kartasura
column3: and his younger brother and heir apparent to the throne
column4: Prince Mangkubumi (later known as Hamengkubuwono I
column5: the first Sultan of Yogyakarta
column6: and the founder of the current ruling royal house). Pakubuwono II had agreed to cooperate with the Dutch East India Company
column7: and ceded some Mataram territory to the Dutch. His younger brother
column10: citing concerns that the people would become slaves under Dutch rule. During the war
column11: Prince Mangkubumi defeated Pakubuwono II's forces and declared sovereignty in the Sultanate of Yogyakarta
column12: occupying the southern parts of the former Mataram Sultanate.

column1: With Pakubowono II dead from illness
column2: the Yogyakarta Sultanate was established as a result of the Treaty of Giyanti (Perjanjian Gianti)
column3: signed and ratified on 13 February 1755 among Prince Mangkubumi
column4: the Dutch East India Company
column5: and his nephew Pakubuwono III and his allies. Ascending to the newly-created Yogyakarta throne with the name Sultan Hamengkubuwono I
column6: Mangkubumi thus established the royal House of Hamengkubuwono
column7: still the ruling house of Yogyakarta today. Sultan Hamengkubuwono I and his family officially moved into the Palace of Yogyakarta
column8: still the seat of the reigning sultan
column9: on 7 October 1756. These events consequently marked the end of the Mataram Sultanate
column10: resulting in the births of the rival Yogyakarta Sultanate and the Surakarta Sunanate.

column1: During the British occupation of Java in 1811
column2: rumours of plans by the Yogyakarta court to stage a rebellion caused uneasiness among the colonial authorities. On 20 June 1812
column3: Stamford Raffles led a 1
column4: 200-strong British force to attack the royal city. The Javanese
column5: surprised by the attack
column6: were easily subdued; Yogyakarta fell in one day
column7: with the city destroyed and its palace looted. The event completely stripped the Sultanate of its remaining power and influence. The sack also left the court humiliated and ultimately fuelled a rebellion against the Dutch
column8: which would be known as the Java War (1825–1830).

column2: the Japanese Empire invaded the Dutch East Indies and ruled Java until they were defeated in 1945. Sukarno proclaimed the independence of the Indonesian Republic on 17 August 1945; Sultan Hamengkubuwono IX promptly sent a letter to Sukarno
column3: expressing his support for the newly born nation of Indonesia and acknowledging the Yogyakarta Sultanate as part of the Indonesian Republic. The Sultanate of Surakarta did the same
column4: and both of the Javanese kingdoms were accordingly awarded privileged statuses as "Special Regions" within the Indonesian Republic. However
column5: because of a leftist anti-royalist uprising in Surakarta
column6: the Sunanate of Surakarta lost its special administrative status in 1946 and was absorbed into Central Java Province.

column1: Yogyakarta's support was essential in the Indonesian struggle for independence during the Indonesian National Revolution (1945–1949). The city of Yogyakarta became the capital of the Indonesian Republic from 1946 to 1948
column2: after the fall of Jakarta to the Dutch. Later the Dutch also invaded Yogyakarta
column3: causing the Republic's capital to be transferred once again
column4: to Bukittinggi in West Sumatra on 19 December 1948. The General Offensive of 1 March 1949 resulted in an Indonesian political and strategic victory against the Dutch and the withdrawal of Dutch forces from Yogyakarta. On 29 June 1949 Yogyakarta was completely cleared of Dutch forces
column5: under pressure from the United Nations.

column1: Because of its significant contribution to the survival of the Indonesian Republic
column2: Yogyakarta was given autonomy as a "special district"
column3: making it the only region headed by a recognised monarchy in Indonesia.

column1: The area of the city of Yogyakarta is 32.5 square kilometres (12.5 square miles). While the city spreads in all directions from the Kraton
column2: the Sultan's palace

column4: centred around Dutch colonial-era buildings and the commercial district. Jalan Malioboro
column5: with rows of pavement vendors and nearby markets and malls

column9: is the shopping district more frequented by locals. The large local market of Beringharjo (id) and the restored Dutch fort of Vredeburg are on the eastern part of the southern end of Malioboro.

column1: Surrounding the Kraton is a densely populated residential neighbourhood that occupies land that was formerly the Sultan's sole domain. Evidence of this former use remains in the form of old walls
column2: scattered throughout the city
column3: and the ruins of the Taman Sari water castle
column4: built in 1758 as a pleasure garden. No longer in use by the Sultan
column5: the garden was largely abandoned before being used for housing by palace employees and descendants. Reconstruction efforts began in 2004
column6: and the site is now a popular tourist attraction.

column1: Nearby to the city of Yogyakarta is Mount Merapi
column2: with the northern outskirts of the city running up to the southern slopes of the mountain in Sleman Regency. Mount Merapi (literally "mountain of fire" in both Indonesian and Javanese)
column3: is an active stratovolcano located on the border between Central Java and Yogyakarta. It is the most active volcano in Indonesia and has erupted regularly since 1548
column4: with the last eruption occurring in May 2018.

column1: Yogyakarta features a tropical monsoon climate (Am) as the precipitation in the driest month
column2: August is below 60 millimetres (2.4 inches). The wettest month in Yogyakarta is January with precipitation totalling 392 millimetres (15.4 inches). The climate is influenced by the monsoon. The annual temperature is roughly about 26 to 27 Celsius. The hottest month is April with average temperature 27.1 Celsius.

Gross Domestic Regional Product (GRDP) of Yogyakarta City at current price were 31.31 trillion rupiahs. Tertiary sector played an important role on economy. It covered category of wholesale and retail trade; repair of cars and motorcycles
column3: transportation and warehousing; provision of accommodation and eating and drinking; categories of information and communication; categories of financial services and insurance; real estate; corporate services; government administration
column4: defence and compulsory social security; educational services; health services and social activities as well as the other services category. The contribution of this tertiary sector to GRDP was 78.28 percent. In 2017
column5: economic growth of Yogyakarta City reached 5.24 percent slightly faster compared to 2016
column6: which the growth reached 5.11 percent.

column3: and contains a museum displaying royal artefacts. Tugu monument is an important landmark of Yogyakarta. 1 March monument located on Jalan Malioboro was built to commemorate General Offensive of 1 March 1949 during the Indonesian National Revolution.

column1: Gudeg Yogya: a traditional food from Yogyakarta and Central Java made from young unripe nangka (jack fruit) boiled for several hours with palm sugar and coconut milk. This is usually accompanied by opor ayam (chicken in coconut milk)
column2: telur pindang (hard boiled egg stew)
column3: and krechek (spicy beef skin and tofu stew). Gudeg from Yogyakarta has a unique sweet and savoury taste
column4: and is drier and more reddish than other regional variants because of the addition of Javanese teak leaf.

column1: Krechek (or krecek or sambal goreng krechek): a traditional spicy beef skin dish made from seasoned krupuk kulit (beef skin crackers). Krechek is usually served as a side dish together with gudeg.
Ayam goreng Kalasan: chicken stewed in coriander

column1: Kipo: derived from the Javanese question Iki opo? ("What is this?")
column2: a small sweet snack from Kotagede made of glutinous rice flour and coconut milk dough filled with grated coconut and palm sugar.

column1: To the east of the town centre is the large Air Force Museum (Museum Pusat Dirgantara Mandala)
column2: with 36 aircraft in the building and six aircraft displayed outdoors. As Indonesia was for a period in the Soviet sphere of influence
column3: this museum contains a number of vintage Russian aircraft not widely available for inspection in the NATO sphere of influence. The collection includes examples of the Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-15 trainer

column1: Yogyakarta is home to Gadjah Mada University
column2: Indonesia's largest university and one of its most prominent. Other public universities in Yogyakarta include Yogyakarta State University
column3: Sunan Kalijaga Islamic University
column4: and the Indonesian Institute of the Arts. The city is also the location of several well-known private universities such as Muhammadiyah University of Yogyakarta

column8: Duta Wacana Christian University and Sanata Dharma University.

column1: Yogyakarta is served by Yogyakarta International Airport
column2: which connects the city with other major cities in Indonesia
column3: such as Jakarta
column4: Surabaya

column6: Lombok
column12: and Pontianak. It also internationally connects the city with Kuala Lumpur (operated by AirAsia and Indonesia AirAsia) and Singapore (operated by Silkair).

column1: Yogyakarta was first served by rail in 1872. The city is located on one of the two major railway lines that run across Java between Jakarta in the west and Surabaya in the east.
Yogyakarta has two passenger railway stations
column2: Yogyakarta Station which serves business and executive class trains
column3: and Lempuyangan Station which serves economy class trains; both stations are located in the centre of the city. Commuter train include the Prambanan Express (Prameks)
column4: which runs from Lempuyangan Station to Solo Balapan Station in the city of Surakarta
column5: and Kutoarjo Station in Kutoarjo. Other commuter trains run from Madiun Jaya (Madiun Station-Lempuyangan Station)
column6: and Joglosemar (Semarang Poncol Station-Lempuyangan Station).

column1: The city has an extensive system of public city buses

column3: as well as taxis
column4: andongs
column5: and becaks. Motorbikes are by far the most commonly used personal transportation
column6: but an increasing number of residents own automobiles. Yogyakarta also has a highway known as the Ringroad and overpasses including Janti Overpass
column8: and a recently built overpass in the northern part of the Ringroad.
